This is the dumbest conspiracy I have ever heard. Firstly, the plane that 
flew over the building was a C-130 plane, probably military. Secondly, from 
the way the building collapsed, it is obvious that it started collapsing 
from the bottom, so it couldn't have been a bomb from the plane. Thirdly, 
the reason why the plane didn't not fly over the building was because there 
was a dust cloud and flying into the dust cloud would affect the fuselage 
and also block the cockpit glasses. It i so funny that I am just 14 years 
old and I have been able to explain what happened but some Nigerian are 
claiming that the plane had something to do with the building collapsing. 
It just shows how senseless and obtuse some Nigerians are.    ﻿

We don't know what the plane was doing, but it was strange that a military 
Hercules C-130 was in that part of Ikotun Egbe just before the incident. 
Commercial jets fly over that area (at a greater height) on the flight path 
to or from the airport regularly, but this was not at all normal. 
A spokesman said during the inquest that it was "on a circuit training 
mission".
In an apparent attempt to bolster this version of events, the same aircraft 
was seen again flying very low a number of times over the church buildings 
on the first day of the inquest and then again on 29 October 2014, another 
important inquest day. Rather than suggesting that circuit training flights 
of military transport planes over these residential areas are a normal 
occurrence,  these subsequent sightings of the Nigerian Air Force Hercules 
C130 close to the church buildings only deepen the mystery of what the 
plane was doing immediately before the collapse on 12 September. Were these 
subsequent flights some kind of unsubtle cover-up? For more on this and 
more pictures of the plane, see truthwillprevail2015.wordpress.com﻿

This is by FAR the DUMBEST conspiracy theory crap I've ever seen in my 
entire life.

The aircraft is is not "strange" at all, it's simply a C-130 Hercules. It 
is NOT flying over the building at all, it wasn't even flying in close 
enough proximity to drop any kind of explosive devices on the building.

it is no less than 3 to 5 MILES away from the building and it keeps flying 
over because it's on a normal looping pattern waiting in line to land at 
the Murtala Muhammad International Airport that's only a few miles away 
from the church. That's something that happens at every large airport every 
single day around the world.

Google Maps is a thing now folks, give it a shot.  The satellite view of 
that airport shows more than a dozen C-130 Hercules aircraft sitting on the 
ground in various paint schemes.

The timestamps on the video also prove that there are no less than 2 
different C-130 aircraft looping the airport waiting to land because 
there's no way in hell that a Hercules could complete a loop of that 
airport in only 2 minutes.  There was also no less than 50 minutes between 
the last pass of the C-130 and the building implosion.

At the very least you can blame shoddy construction for the building's 
collapse, at the most you could blame a very deliberately set up implosion 
of the type used on hundreds of other large buildings to drop them in their 
place without damaging other structures.

Somewhere in the middle of those two things you might find a suicide bomber 
that blew himself up just to bring down a non-islamic church in the middle 
of a VERY heavily islamic country.

This was a terrorist attack, plain and simple.﻿

+IvyOrtizRocks
It's not strange at all to see C-130 cargo planes flying circles around an 
international airport just 4.7 miles away from the church, an airport that 
also houses military aircraft, Google Maps, Satellite View, use it.

It doesn't matter where you live, the same thing happens all around the 
world.  Go to your local large airport, look up in the sky, you will see 
numerous aircraft circling the field *waiting* *in* *line* *to* *land*.

They can't all land at once because they would crash into eachother in the 
air and on the ground. Landing permission is handed out on a first come 
first serve basis, with room for emergency landings if they need to happen.

All aircraft take off with more fuel than they need to accommodate for busy 
airports where they're forced to wait in line to land.

So *NO*, aircraft circling an airport is NOT "strange" at all, it's 
something that happens every single day at every major airport all around 
the world.

Also check out *www.flightradar24.com* and you might be amazed at just how 
many aircraft are in the sky at once all around the world.

Each time the aircraft flies by, it's following approximately the same 
path.  It's circling around a point perhaps three or five kilometres beyond 
the building; when a pilot is circling a point, the point around which he's 
circling is the point of interest. If the pilot had been interested in the 
SCOAN, it would have been circling the SCOAN, not passing over it every few 
minutes. Passing directly over a building in the course of circling is 
probably the *worst* possible way to observe it.

Why would it be circling?  There are many plausible reasons, such as a 
training flight, or holding until an airport could grant it clearance to 
land.

Could vibrations induced by a low-flying plane trigger a building 
collapse?  Yes.  I'm sure it's happened, sometime, somewhere. It might even 
have happened here. But a building that could collapse in response to such 
a small impulse is a building that's already so intolerably, irresponsibly 
weak that it's primed to come down at any moment, in response to any 
trigger or no particular trigger at all.

And sure, the aircraft disappears after the building collapse. There's 
nothing surprising or mysterious about that. A responsible pilot is *not* 
going to fly a large air-breathing aircraft through a cloud of concrete 
dust, or occupy airspace that's likely to be filled with rescue helicopters 
at any moment. A responsible pilot is going to be promptly taking his plane 
somewhere else.  He will probably be ordered to, not that a pilot worthy of 
a licence would need an order to avoid such an obvious safety risk.﻿
